coredata.dc:title: Ab initio calculations concerning the reaction mechanism of the copper(II) catalyzed glycine condensation in aqueous sodium chloride solution
coredata.dc:creator: Liedl, Klaus R.
Rode, Bernd M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Starting from results of detailed experimental work concerning the copper(II) catalyzed glycine condensation, quantum-mechanical studies of species which should be relevant for the reaction mechanism are presented. This reaction is of special interest because it could be important in explaining the formation of the first peptides on prebiotic earth. SCF geometry optimizations of aquo-chloro-glycinato—copper(II) complexes at Hartree—Fock level were performed especially to study the necessity of chlorine for the reaction. In that way a hypothetical reaction mechanism could be confirmed. Structural distortions as expected from the Jahn—Teller effect resulted from optimizations of copper complexes in C1 geometry.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 Ab initio calculations concerning the reaction mechanism of the copper(II) catalyzed glycine condensation in aqueous sodium chloride solution Klaus R. Liedl and Bernd M. Rode Subdivision of Theoretical Chemistry, Institute of lnorganic and Analytical Chemistry, University of lnnsbruck, Innrain 52a, A-6020 Innsbruck, Austria Received 26 May 1992 Starting from results of detailed experimental work concerning the copper(ll ) catalyzed glycine condensation, quantum-me- chanical studies of species which should be relevant for the reaction mechanism are presented. This reaction is of special interest because it could be important in explaining the formation of the first peptides on prebiotic earth. SCF geometry optimizations of aquo-chloro-glycinato-copper (II) complexes at Hartree-Fock level were performed especially to study the necessity of chlorine for the reaction. In that way a hypothetical reaction mechanism could be confirmed. Structural distortions as expected from the Jahn-Teller effect resulted from optimizations of copper complexes in C1 geometry. 1. Introduction Within the last few years a new concept has been presented to give a simple explanation how the for- mation of the first peptides on prebiotic earth could have taken place [ 1-4 ]. The main concepts of this explanation are the water-removing force of concen- trated salt solutions and the catalytic effect of metal ions. Detailed investigations have shown that cop- per(II) is able to catalyze the reaction much more than any other of the tested metal ions. For the cat- ion of the water-removing salt there seems to be a relatively free choice, but the anion chloride seems to be essential. Therefore the experimental back- ground of the reaction system is given by a concen- trated sodium chloride solution with copper(II) chloride as catalyst. To characterize this reaction mixture in more de- tail potentiometric and spectrophotometric titra- tions have been performed [ 6] to find out the spe- cies distribution in the system. It was found that under the given conditions copper(II) is mainly bound to one or two chlorine and one or two glycine ligands. The pH region where the reaction takes place is especially characterized by the fact that reorgan- ization processes take place where a second glycine ligand approaches and leaves the copper(II) complexes. For detailed studies four main complex species where chosen (in the following gly is the deproton- ated chelate ligand, glyH is the zwitterionic glycine and glyH2 the double protonated carboxylate coor- dinating glycine ligand ): [ Cu (H20) 6 ] 2 +, [CuCI(H20)5]+, [ CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2 ]/, [Cu (gly) (glyH2) (H20)3 ]2+ The first two of these complexes represent impor- tant species in the reaction mixture, whereas the sec- ond two species are important for the understanding of the reaction mechanism of the glycine conden- sation. In both cases the effects of building the ion pair between copper(II) and chloride was of special interest because these effects should supply an ex- planation for the necessity of the presence of chlo- ride for the glycine condensation. Correspondence to." B.M. Rode, Subdivision of Theoretical Chemistry, Institute of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, Uni- versity of Innsbruck, Innrain 52a, A-6020 Innsbruck, Austria. 2. Method All SCF ab initio calculations were performed at 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 181 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 Hartree-Fock level using the program packages from the HONDO and GAUSSIAN series [7,8]. Most of the presented results were obtained by using the pro- gram GAUSSIAN 90. The influence of the choice of basis sets was stud- ied by over fifty geometry optimizations of various subsystems. The basis set in ref. [9] with the con- traction [2, 1/1, 1/4, 1] for copper and CEP-31G* [ 12-14 ] for all other involved atoms seems to be a good compromise between reducing calculation time and guaranteeing the quality of the results within the limits of the method. Polarization functions on hy- drogens did not yield considerable improvement of the quality of the calculations and therefore were omitted. Problems as pointed out for the calcula- tions of copper(II)-ligand energy surfaces [ 15 ] do not appear, mainly because all distances are close to equilibrium geometry. To achieve convergence during the SCF procedure the direct inversion in the iterative subspace (DIIS) method proposed by Pulay [ 16,17 ] was normally used. If problems occurred the quadratically con- vergent Hartree-Fock (QC) method by Bacskay [ 18 ] succeeded. 3. Results 3.1. [Cu(H20)6]2+ In the case of [Cu(H20)6]2+ quite early calcu- lations are reported in the literature [25 ]. The Jahn- Teller effect was also studied using ab initio calcu- lations [ 26 ]. Therefore two completely independent geometry optimizations to the default convergence criteria of the GAUSSIAN 90 program were per- formed. First the geometry of this species was op- timized in Th symmetry. For the mentioned com- bination of basis sets the following results were obtained. The copper-oxygen distance was found to be 2.16 A, and the water geometry resulted with an oxygen-hydrogen distance of 0.95 /k and an intra- molecular angle of 108.0 . The Mulliken charges (which are not physically observable and should only be considered in comparison with the Mulliken charges of calculations within the same combination of basis sets) were found to be + 1.41 on copper and -0.90 on oxygen. A second geometry optimization starting with slightly dissymmetrized coordinates gave a com- pletely different result concerning the coordination geometry, reflecting the Jahn-Teller effect. Four of the six water ligands (equatorial) were found to have a copper-oxygen distance of 2.10 A and the two other (axial) copper-oxygen distances were about 2.28 A, which is in reasonable accordance with experimental EXAFS spectroscopy data [ 19 ]. Although calcula- tions of highly symmetric species tend to yield much lower energies than those using an only marginally different CI geometry (as could be proven in the above-mentioned geometry optimizations of subsys- tems) a 1.2 kcal mol-t lower energy was obtained for C1 than for Th symmetry which is insignificant within the limits of the method. Also Mulliken charges and geometric parameters of the ligands were very similar to those obtained using Th symmetry. The four nearer coordinated water molecules have an average intramolecular angle of 108.4 , whereas the value for the distant two ligands is 107.2 . 3.2. [CuCI(H20)5]+ In comparison to the previously described [Cu(H20)6]2+ species the [CuCI(H20)5]/ com- plex which was also geometry optimized in C 1 sym- metry shows an even more pronounced preference for four of the six ligands. Namely chloride with a copper-chloride distance of 2.25/~ and three water ligands with 2.15, 2.15 and 2.08 A form a plane of closer ligands in comparison to the two axial ligands with an average copper-oxygen distance of 2.44/~. The water molecule in trans position to the chloride ligand has the shortest coordination distance. The water angles vary from 110.5 for the closest ligand through 107.9 for the water molecules at medium distance to 108.1 for the two distant water ligands. The oxygen-hydrogen distances within the water li- gands remain constant at 0.95 A. The main differ- ence to the previously discussed [Cu(H20)6]2+ complex is obviously the charge distribution. Cop- per receives much more electron density from the chloride ligand than it can attract from water li- gands. Its Mulliken charge is + 1.05 whereas the chloride has a charge of -0.51. Therefore a small amount of electron density is even transferred to the water ligands. The charge transfer is in this case and 182 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 in all other discussed species not a reduction process of copper(II) to copper(I) but only an internal po- larization of the whole complex. This can be seen from the spin density on copper being 1.04. The ob- served small displacement of spin density can be ver- ified by the widening of peaks in NMR spectra of comparable compounds [ 20 ]. 3. 3. Bis-glycinato-copper(II) complexes The choice of the the principle geometry and the coordination types of the [CuCl(gly)(glyH2)- (H20)2 ] + complex was guided by the following hy- pothesis concerning the reaction mechanism. Obviously the formation of a peptide bond during the reaction needs a nucleophilic attack of a glycine amino group to the electrophilic carboxylate group of another glycine molecule. In solution this attack normally cannot take place, because depending on pH value either the amino group is protonated or the carboxylate group is deprotonated. In both cases the reaction is not favoured so that the reaction does nearly not occur at all in the absence of copper(II) ions. But if a glycine molecule is coordinated to cop- per(II) as chelate ligand, its amino group is depro- tonated and it should be possible that glycine could act as nucleophil even in relatively acidic solution. From the species distribution it is known that in so- lution protonated and deprotonated glycine ligands are present. The deprotonated glycine ligands are chelate-coordinated whereas the protonated glycine ligands are carboxylate-coordinated rather than amino-coordinated. Further, the optimum reaction conditions are within the pH region where upon de- crease of the proton concentration the number of complexes with two glycine ligands increases at the cost of complexes with one glycine ligand [3,4 ]. Fi- nally the best yields of diglycine are found at a cop- per-glycine ratio of l : 2 [ 4 ]. For these reasons it is most likely that the con- densation of glycine is realized via an intermediate which is a complex of copper(II) with two glycine ligands in its first coordination sphere (fig. 1 ). If one of the glycine ligands is deprotonated and the other one is protonated, this complex would exhibit an op- timum structure for a nucleophilic attack of the de- protonated amino group on the protonated carbox- ylate group. Only the necessity of chloride has no H CI 111 ICI H Fig. 1. Structure of [CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2] + complex. H H ++C H HI ( H O2H (~ ~ltl O6 It Fig. 2. Structure of [Cu(gly) (glyH2) (020)3]2+ complex. simple explanation at this state of considerations. Therefore the choice of the complexes which should be treated by quantum-mechanical tools was to include a [ CuC1 (gly) (glyH2) ( n20 ) 2 ] + complex which has a protonated carboxylate-coordinated gly- cine ligand in its first coordination sphere. The re- sults for this species were to be compared with a complex of the same structure concerning glycine li- gands but instead of the chloro ligand there should be another water ligand (fig. 2). This comparison should give the possibility to get indications con- cerning the role of chloride for the reaction. Because both species are too large for a complete geometry optimization within reasonable computing time, the starting geometry was built from com- pletely optimized substructures. The complexes were optimized to root mean square forces of 0.006 har- tree bohr- 1 and a maximum force of 0.024 hartree bohr-' in the case of the [CuCl(gly)(glyH2)- (H20)2]+ complex and root mean square forces of 0.002 hartree bohr-1 and a maximum force of 0.010 hartree bohr- 1 in the case of the [Cu(gly) (glyH2) (H20)3]2+ complex. Comparing the geometry results of the two cal- 183 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 culations the strong influence of the chloride ligand is obvious (table 1 ). Especially the coordination dis- tance of the protonated glycine ligand is extremely enlarged in the presence of the chloride ligand. Also the two water molecules have a significantly larger distance to the central copper whereas the coordi- nation of the remaining chelate ligand is nearly not influenced by chloride. The geometry of the chelate system is in good accordance with X-ray diffraction experiments [ 21-23 ]. Looking at the Mulliken charges of the coordinat- ing atoms the well-known effect of strong central positive charges can be observed (table 2) The more positive the central charge the more electron density is transferred from the peripheral parts of the ligands to the coordinating atoms. In comparison to the geo- metric effects of chloride coordination its electronic effects on the other ligands are relatively small. 3.4. Energetic overview The energetic results are important for the inter- pretation of the chemical relevance of the presented structures. Therefore their absolute and relative sta- Table 1 Coordination distances of ligands (A,) Ligand Coordinating atom [ CuCI ( ply ) ( gtyH2 ) (H20) 2 ] + [ Cu ( ply ) (glyH2) ( H20 ) 3 ] 2 + glycine (chelate) 05 1.96 (05) 1.92 (05) N1 2.07 (N1) 2.08 (NI) glycine (protonated) 02 2.90 (02) 2.37 (02) water O1 - 2.07 (Ol) 03 2.60 (03) 2.46 (03) 04 2.63 (04) 2.41 (04) chloride Cl 2.14 (Cl) - Table 2 Mulliken charges of atoms Atom (ligand) [CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2 ] + [Cu(gly) (glyH2) (H20)3]2+ Cu +0.85 + 1.12 Cl/Ol (chloride/water) -0.52 -0.86 02 (glycine, protonated) - 0.02 - 0.13 03 (water) -0.84 -0.87 04 (water) -0.83 -0.87 05 (glycine, chelate ) - 0.45 - 0.46 Nl (glycine, chelate) -0.75 -0.81 C l (glycine, protonated) - 0. l 0 - 0.06 06 (glycine, protonated ) - 0.41 - 0.37 H l (glycine, protonated ) + 0.49 + 0.50 Table 3 Mulliken charges of functional groups Functional group (central atom) [CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2] + [Cu(gly) (glyH2) (H20)3]2+ chloride/water (O 1 ) - 0.52 carboxylate group of protonated glycine (C 1 ) - 0.04 water (O3) + 0.06 water (04) +0.05 carboxylate group of chelate-coordinated glycine (C2) -0.68 amino group of chelate-coordinated glycine (N1) -0.02 +0.13 -0.06 +0.07 +0.07 -0.64 -0.05 184 Volume 197, number 1,2 Table 4 Absolute and relative stabilization energies CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 Species AEab, (kcal mol- 1 ) AE~ (kcal mol- ~ ) exp(-AE~I/RT) [Cu(n20)6]2+ -- 343.6 0.0 1.00 [Cu (gly) (glyH2) (H20)3 ]2+ -373.8 -30.2 1.04 [CuCI(H20)5] / - 544.3 -200.7 1.33 [CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2]+ -551.9 -208.3 1.35 bilization energies are given using [Cu (H20) 6 ] 2 / as reference (table 4). The stabilization energies were calculated based on the zwitterionic form of glycine as reference for this ligand. It can be seen from the high stabilization energy of the [CuCl(gly) (glyH2) (H20)2] / complex that a complex of this structure can easily exist in the re- action mixture which is dominated by the [ CuC1 (H20) 5 ] / species. Looking at the Boltzmann factors of the complexes the much stronger stabili- zation of complexes with chloride ligands is in good agreement with the fact that the reaction mixture is dominated by copper(II) chloride ion pair species [ 6 ]. Nevertheless the stabilization energies and the Boltzmann factors should be interpreted with some reservation, because the solvation effects of ligands and complexes were not taken into account; it was assumed that these values would be similar for all subsystems under considerations. 4. Discussion The strong stabilization energy of the [CuC1- (H20) 5 ] / complex reflects the dominance of this species in the reaction mixture as known from ex- perimental measurements [ 6 ] and from simulations [ 10,24 ]. The strong geometric effects due to the for- mation of the ion pair are also found in the case of the glycinato complexes. The stronger binding of four of the six coordination sites as predicted by the Jahn- Teller effect can be reproduced throughout the cal- culations. The internal polarization of the glycinato complexes on forming the ion pair with chloride is reduced by the chelate ligand. Still the reactive centres of the [CuCl(gly)(glyH2) (H20)2] / complex are stabilized in their active form by these small polar- ization effects. It is remarkable that both the coor- dinating carboxylate group of the protonated glycine and the amino group of the chelate-coordinated gly- cine lose electron density to the complex whereas the carboxylate group of the chelate ligand receives elec- tron density in the presence of the chloride ligand. Although the stabilization energies as well as the Mulliken charges suggest the idea that the role of chloride is mainly not an electronic one, it is more likely to suppose that the strong ligand chloride re- duces the amount of relatively inert di-aquo-bis-che- late-glycine complex through the occupation of one coordination site of copper. This effect is promoted by increase of proton concentration which disables the coordination of the amino group by protonation. The elimination of water which is very important for the completion of the reaction is also favoured by the coordination of chloride to the glycinato-cop- per(II) system as can be seen from the Mulliken charge at the hydroxyl-oxygen (06) of the carbox- ylate group of the protonated glycine. Finally the peptide copper(II) complex is much weaker than the amino-acid-copper(II) complex [ 5,11 ]. Therefore the reaction product is removed from the reactive copper(II) center and the equilibrium is shifted to- ward the direction of peptide formation. 5. Conclusions The following hypothesis concerning the reaction mechanism of the copper(II) catalyzed glycine con- densation in aqueous sodium chloride solution seems to be reasonable on basis of the quantum-mechani- cal calculations: The active species enabling the re- action is the chloro-mono-glycinato-copper(II) complex where the glycine is chelate coordinated. This complex is binding a second glycine molecule through its carboxylate group - chloride prevents chelate coordination of this second ligand. In that arrangement peptide formation has an optimum 185 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 chance to take place due to the spatial proximity of a deprotonated amino group and a protonated car- boxylate group. [26] M. Sano and H. Yamatera, Chem. Letters (1980) 1495. 186 ves elec- tron density in the presence of the chloride ligand. Although the stabilization energies as well as the Mulliken charges suggest the idea that the role of chloride is mainly not an electronic one, it is more likely to suppose that the strong ligand chloride re- duces the amount of relatively inert di-aquo-bis-che- late-glycine complex through the occupation of one coordination site of copper. This effect is promoted by increase of proton concentration which disables the coordination of the amino group by protonation. The elimination of water which is very important for the completion of the reaction is also favoured by the coordination of chloride to the glycinato-cop- per(II) system as can be seen from the Mulliken charge at the hydroxyl-oxygen (06) of the carbox- ylate group of the protonated glycine. Finally the peptide copper(II) complex is much weaker than the amino-acid-copper(II) complex [ 5,11 ]. Therefore the reaction product is removed from the reactive copper(II) center and the equilibrium is shifted to- ward the direction of peptide formation. 5. Conclusions The following hypothesis concerning the reaction mechanism of the copper(II) catalyzed glycine con- densation in aqueous sodium chloride solution seems to be reasonable on basis of the quantum-mechani- cal calculations: The active species enabling the re- action is the chloro-mono-glycinato-copper(II) complex where the glycine is chelate coordinated. This complex is binding a second glycine molecule through its carboxylate group - chloride prevents chelate coordination of this second ligand. In that arrangement peptide formation has an optimum 185 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 chance to take place due to the spatial proximity of a deprotonated amino group and a protonated car- boxylate group. head.ce:title: Ab initio calculations concerning the reaction mechanism of the copper(II) catalyzed glycine condensation in aqueous sodium chloride solution

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Starting from results of detailed experimental work concerning the copper(II) catalyzed glycine condensation, quantum-mechanical studies of species which should be relevant for the reaction mechanism are presented. This reaction is of special interest because it could be important in explaining the formation of the first peptides on prebiotic earth. SCF geometry optimizations of aquo-chloro-glycinato—copper(II) complexes at Hartree—Fock level were performed especially to study the necessity of chlorine for the reaction. In that way a hypothetical reaction mechanism could be confirmed. Structural distortions as expected from the Jahn—Teller effect resulted from optimizations of copper complexes in C1 geometry.
